text: 750ml bottle shared with brother, thanks for the share. Aroma: wow. Amazing complex aroma of white wine aroma, fresh apples, pear, some funk. App: hazy light golden, minimal white head leaving little lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, moderate carbonation, crisp acidity finish. Overall: Ive had almost every variants except the regular version. This is just amazing. I much prefer the original version. This feels so complex. So well done. Amazing. Really love this one.

One of the best beers Ive ever had. Gold pour, smaller head, tiny ring of lace. Aroma and taste is rustic, tart, white wine, light oak, wheat, yeast. Perfect mouthfeel, lighter carbonation, lighter body.

2016 bottle. This is an incredible beer. Im biased, since I love Hill Farmstead and Florence is my favorite saison that they make. However, this is impressive in its own right. Its subtle and seriously restrained. Theres a lot of funk smell, with that characteristic HF complex yeast aroma, but the taste is extremely light and balanced. The funk aroma drops away, leaving a bit of acidity, a bit of oak, and some nice lemon flavor. It doesnt try to beat you over the head with a huge wine barrel flavor or a ton of heavy Brett funk; instead, this is light and complex, and really wonderful.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2017 Batch 2017. Bottled splited 4 ways. Very pale golden slighlty hazy liquid with a white head diminishing fast. Shy nose, winy, white grape, slight funk, tartness. Taste is quite disappointing, light body, light floral taste, some citrus sourness, white wine, I lot of hype around this one that I think doesnt deserve it. Florence in my opinion deserves more respect for the taste vs price.
750ml bottle pours out a straw color topped with a white head. Nose is nice funk notes wine barrel touch some spice. Taste is more of the wine barrel notes oak floral perfume notes and some funk.
Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshare goodbye Aaron edition (or not?). Light hazy golden pour with a small head. Notes of grapes, citric, crisp, some green apples, sweet white wine and some pleasant funk.

From bottle thanks to Bursprak at Dangerous Bottleshares - See You In August Aaron Edition! Pours a hazy golden yellow with a big, white head. Aroma has stone fruits, oak, sweet white wine, vanilla, esters, vanilla, grapes. Taste is pretty sour, dry, spicy, subtle fruity sweetness. Smooth body and a medim high carbonation. Very nice!

Dangerous bottle share goodbye Aaron edition. Bottle thanks to Erik. Pours unclear yellow with a white head. Aroma of flowers, barnyard, pear, elderflower, bright vinous notes, peach, slight stone fruits and bread crust. Extremely petite and beautiful aroma - just like Erik. Taste of citrus, orange, slight stone fruits, white pears, floral notes, white wine, barnyard and slight bread. Really easy drinkable and balanced beer. Suns out guns out!

Bottle @ Aarons Last Visit. Pours hazy pale yellow with a medium white head. Aromas of peach, sweet vinous, oaky, estery, lemon zest, wheaty, sweet floral notes. Taste is sweet peachy, citrussy, lemony, floral, sweet vinous, grapey, oaky, light lactic tart.

St Davids Day 2017 - Bottle share at Leightons 20K. Huge thanks and congrats to LKS. As Hill Farmstead Flora. Hazy golden orange, still with a foamy off-white head that leaves full lacing. Aroma is dried citrus fruits, some oak and apple. Body is light, a little frothy in the mouth with tingly carbonation. Taste is minerally, slightly tart, touches of apple, subtle oak, crisp finish. Very easy going. Its an extremely drinkable beer but not a wow beer for me. (3.8)

75cl bottle shared at Leightons Penthouse for his 20K. Special thanks to Leighton himself for this beer. It pours a hazed light golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is funky and tart with notes of white wine, oak, gooseberries, white grapes, lemon. Taste is floral tart citric with notes of lemon peel, white grapes, oak, white wine, lemon juice. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, very good

Bottle shared at the Leighton mega 20k tasting. 1/03/2017. Huge thanks to Leighton for this one. A light hazed pale yellow straw coloured pour with a a lasting white head. Aroma is funky grapey, sour, lychee, saison yeast. Flavour is composed of crisp tart, pithy lemon, bretty, funky grapey fruits, woody tannin. Palate is tart and refreshing, pithy, drying finish, frothy carbonation. Good. Nice hill Farmstead yeast. Good.

Bottle shared in London for the 20k - sourced from the brewery. Pours clear yellow-gold with a frothy, white head. Restrained aroma, some lemon peel, flaked wheat, subtle yeast, minimal funk. Light sweet flavour with quite modest lemony tang, some melon, woody dryness, white wine, citrus peel. Light bodied with delicate, massaging carbonation. Super clean finish, more lightly tart lemon, restrained wheaty sweetness, some straw, soft funk. Subtle to an incredible level, but still nicely layered. Hugely drinkable. Excellent.

750ml bottle purchased for on site consumption. Pours bright yellow. Hazy with a large foamy head with smooth carbonated bubbles with great lacing as well. Smells very winey, smooth and light fruits, tart and sweet with a slight funk to it. Very sweet and winey taste with little fruits as well. The wine barrel really adds to this one. Nice floral tartniess and a great funky sourness. Smooth, light tarty mouthfeel. Delightful and refreshing. Delicious.
Sample from at bottle. Hazy yellow colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of citrus, yeast, spice, vinegar, funk and tartness.

September 3, 2016. Bottle, batch 6. 
Hazy pale yellow with a medium sized white head that sticks to the glass while dissipating. Aroma is fruity, funky and herbal with gooseberries, orange, lemon, some floral notes, menthe. white pepper, oak, white wine and oak. Taste is light sweet, funky, fruity, light bitter and slight tart. Finish is fruity and tart with lemon juice, gooseberries, dry oak and grape skin notes, some earthy herbal and floral notes, brett, overripe fruit notes, hints of barnyard. Light to medium bodied, crisp, slightly dry mouthfeel, average carbonation. 
Great, great balance between the base beer and the barrel notes.

Sample shared at 1st Lambic & Sour Sunday (at Bierhalle Deconinck in Vichte). One of Hill Farmsteads classic farmhouse ales, intended as a saison, but soured with wild fermentation agents and ageing on wine barrels so in practice a true New World sour ale rather than a genuine saison. Moussy, bubbly, snow white head, hazy straw blonde colour with a lime greenish hue, looking a bit like a witbier. Aroma has a wealth of fruity and funky impressions: sour cream, yellow raspberry, vanilla-like oak, lime zest, butter, soggy white bread, dry hay, white grapes, yoghurt, gooseberries... Tart, very fruity and estery flavor, lots of green plum, ripe gooseberry, peach, pear, spritzy but perfectly dosed carbo, supple and smooth, bit creamy mouthfeel. Lemony sourness cuts through it all without being sharply acidic; bready core, soapy wheatiness evident, rounded and complexely and dryingly tart finish with ongoing juicy fruitiness as well as drying wood notes, light wine flavor after swallowing. Beautifully balanced and delicate beer, but as said, much more a modern sour ale than a classic saison.

Due to artificial lighting, arbitrary rating for Appearance  Peaches, lactic acid, lemon, unripe stonefruit. Sour-fruity, peaches, lactic acid, wheat, Bretts in the good way. Quite carbonated, lipsmacking acidity, but  mals . Finally an American sour that remains easily drinkable. Txs to M & L V!
Sample @ Hill Farmstead Tap Takeover, Warpigs. Cloudy light yellow body with a small white head. Floral, light yeasty, fruity, some tartness. Yummy.
Bottle 0,375. Pours hazy amber. Sour, fruits, hay, barn, hint of strawberries, gooseberry, blackberry, blueberry. Medium body and average carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty funky flavor. Has a fruity malty sour tart yeasty finish.
[5/12/16] Bottle at Warpigs in Copenhagen. Cloudy pale yellow. Funky aroma, cobwebs, fruits, a bit of vinegar. Tart flavor, funky, fruity, oak. Medium-bodied. Great stuff.

Draught at Warpigs at the courtesy of Rune. Low fluffy white and quickly disappearing head. Hazy dark red body. Acidic fruity tart black courrant aroma and flavor with mild notes of lemon and brett. High carbonation. Long finish. Nice surprise.
Sample at Warpigs during the HF event. Tart and fruity smell with cassis. Similar taste. Fresh and refreshing.

Bottle @ Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours hazy yellow with a white head, lacings. Aroma of malt, yeast, barnyard, light dusty, wood, hay, white wine grapes, green grapes, little sweet fruit. Flavor is light sour, yeasty, light brett, wood, oak, hay, tart fruit, white wine, wine grapes. Medium body, average carbonation, dry and light acidic finish. 120516
Bottle at warpigs. Aroma of citrus, Lemon and floral. Zesty. The flavour is mainly sour. The body is light and the texture is juicy. Refreshing. Nice one...
Bottle at Warpigs. Cloudy yellow with a small white head. Fruity aroma with white wine, oak, vinegar. Dry and tart flavour with wood, fruit, strawberry and a faint touch of yeast.
Bottle warpigs. Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma of tarty, fruity, sweet, light wheat like notes, flowery. Taste tarty, fruity, flowery, quite complex, light sweet. Very good.

Bottle at Warpigs. It pours cloudy yellow with a creamy white head. Lovely floral aroma with a clean malty backbone. Light acid. Great acidic balanced flavor containing notes of zesty citrus. Highly bitter finish. A treat!
Bottle at war pigs.. Hazy Amber.. Thin white lacing.. Soft floral funk fruit nose... Juicy tart fruit.. Light peach funk... Zezty fruits.. Light bitter funk
Bottle @ Warpigs, tap take over. Hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, bretty, citrus and wood. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 120516
On tap at RateBeer Best 2016. Pour is hazy yellow with a two finger wide white head. Aroma and flavor of peach, mellow funk, grape vines, brett, and oak.

Bottle to taster
Consummation: Dregsy pour, so yeasty sour plum. 
Adjunct: Sweet, fruity aroma, very little sour aromatics. And no plum on the nose either. This is brilliant.

Bottled 2016 01 12 and rated as an American Wild Ale, so not to upset scores on here too much.
This was poured into a tulip. 
The appearance was a hazy burnt yellow to orange color with a one finger white foamy head that quickly dissipated leaving some light messy lacing sliding right on into the beer. 
The smell takes on a quick sour grape to bitter grapefruit and then a subtle grapefruit, semi-sweet grassy contour. Beautifully floral and then a lemony sweet to bitter aroma.
The taste takes on the same aroma roaming into a florally bittersweet dry aftertaste and finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation runs fairly light allowing the sourness to hit as a good penetrator for the harshness. 
Overall, when one rates this as an American Wild Ale, youll see HF will knock it out of the park. Saison, ppff, no way, man, who put that on here? I hope youre embarrassed.

A hazed golden ale with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet fruity malt with loads of citrusy pulp, light tropical fruits, resinous and piney hops, light mineral notes, grassy character, very nice. In mouth, a nice tart sweet fruity malt with lemony notes, citrus pulp beautiful and delicious. Bottle.
A: Yellow coloured with a thin white lacing N: Grapes, juniper berries, lemon T: mandarine orange, lime, lemon O: Nice and fresh with loads of citrus! Very nice!

Bottle at RBWG 2016. Juicy tropical fruit box nose. Reddish purple deep color. A drying mouthfeel at first with a lemon flavor and hay. Some tart berry cherry flavor as it warms. A very drying finish.

Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Aroma is huge lemon candy with light brett, light yogurt and tropical fruit. Tastes awesome. So smooth. Great balance of lemon-y sweet tarts, brett, yogurt, stone fruit, and hay. Big tartness in the finish. Balanced, delicious and crushable.
R U Jokin or wat? Just had this back to back with CD15 and this is just a touch behind. God nectar. Tart, funky, bacterial, oak. Lightly vinous. This is excellence on every level.
25.4oz bottle - B6. Hazy yellow hue. Dry hopped saison nose. Very well balanced wood/barrel, hops, yeast, wine/dry white grape, taste. Medium-body and full carbonation.

750 mL bottle. Batch 3. Originally reviewed 6/28/2013.

Golden orange. A little hazy. Big white head that leaves a bit of lacing and large surface wisps.

Aroma has Earthy notes, akin to brett, without ever being bretty. Lemon zest. Wheat grain. Wine and a hint of acidity.

Strong white wine flavor. Much more acidic, but not sour. Grainy. Bright lemon tang. White wine lingers in the aftertaste.

Light, but the flavors linger well on the palate. Well carbonated. 

Lacking the complexity of the other barrel aged saisons, but still the barrel adds a great deal. Ive learned to appreciate its simplicity, though.

Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of light-moderate florals, lemon, lemon peel, and faint sweet tarts. Its a hazy dull golden-orange with a small white head that fades to a minimal film outlined by a thin ring. The flavor starts with a quick dose of tart citrus. The finish has light-moderate lemon, sweet tarts, and a touch of funk. Its light bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Hazy golden with a medium sized white head. Nose has pepper, grapes, must, wood, cellar. Flavour follows. Medium body. Very musty and rustic. This is a very. Very. Good rating. I am an expert.

Hazy golden colour, white head. Spicy aroma, vanilla, sour lactic acid, somewhat musty. Sweetish flavour, sour, quite spicy, peach notes. Bit herbal finish, light sweetnes, spices. Cool to have drunk batch #1, but think it was a bit on the old side.(from 75cL bottle @ ACBF 2015, Vichte. 2011 vintage, batch #1. Thanks for sharing, tderoeck!!)

batch 5 bottle shared by a friend together with florence. been dying to try this one! poured a straw cloudy golden colour with a white head. nose has a clear notice of funky brett, and white grapes, oak, and tart notes, citrus, and dusty funk. white wine. lactic yoghurt. wheat, and funky tart notes in the finish. a perfect saison transformed into a delicious funky white wine. wow. one of the best wine barrel saisons. cant wait to see if art and ann can beat this one. delicious!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2017 Batch 6 magnum shared by Adam on 7/25/15, with some really enjoyable kid rock playing in the background....sigh.Just a crazy stupendously perfect appearance. Lightly hazy brass with just huge, dense, well-retained, white head atop.Mossy, very earthy plant-like character in the nose is complemented by sulfur/poop-like yeast/bacteria notes that are quite enjoyable. Very nice and restrained on the barrels, no huge wine character and not a ton of tannin dullness. Love the stinky, funky nose and the beer seems very appropriately named. No alcohol or flaws.Soft, gentle floral notes and cornflower-like delicateness creeping in between the moderate acids and light maltiness. Lilacs, mangoes, pineapple, honeyed maltiness and some dry, grainy wheat character. Nice balance on the sweetness/dryness and a fairly thick body. In that sense, the "thickness" or "fullness" from the wheat, the extra body or chewiness from the barrel tannin and the creamy-full texture from the carbonation dont really go together, I dont think, but its still awesomely flavorful and its ok that it drinks a bit bigger than it actually is.Well, I guess Im officially in the Hill Farmstead superfan club, but then, Ive always thought very highly of Shauns brewing (see my reviews for his saisons from his days at the Shed, if you care). These "saisons" are awesome, regardless of how you feel about style guidelines and what is a "true saison". Im not afraid to admit how good they are and jump on the bandwagon with my high reviews. They really were almost unanimously awesome. Adam aging them in a cool cellar for a year via a magnum (which reduces oxidation) certainly didnt hurt either.-End Justification for why I like beers I like.  8/5/8/4/17750mL bottle, B6 again, drunk 11/5/16.With some more time to develop, this has developed more funk, mineral and even sulfur.  Its qute sublime, not overly sour, and still shows plentiful body/texture for 18 months of age.  I love the Flora series in all its iterations and the base beer is no exception.  Upping the score a bit.  Rating is for this experience.

(75 cl. 08/2014. Batch 06. Généreusement partagée par Alex M. Merci!) Belle robe blonde et col blanc qui tombe après quelques gorgées. Au nez, notes fortes de vin. Levures de la maison, blé, effet lactique, touche de vanille. Sur les papilles, moins de complexité : vin blanc, levures indigènes et le blé de Florence. Tout de même agréable mais rien de renversant. En bouche, corps crémeux et pétillement très ou trop bas. En finale, une légère aigreur fruitée. Pas mal.

Magnum shared by AdamChandler opened at Ratebeer Farmhouse Magnum Tasting v1. Kid Rock on the boom box, Clark hating it. Pours yellow gold with an white head. Aroma is wheat, HFS funk, mild oak. Flavor follows, soft, tart, citrus, wheat, a touch of honey, HFS funk.

Poured from magnum batch 6 thanks AdamChandler for the Ratebeer Farmhouse Magnum Tasting. Hazy golden pour with a nice white head. Aromas of tart lemon sour lacto and vanilla hay. Taste is super clean and matches aroma. Nice beer.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2015 Bottle: Batch 6 from a magnum bottle thanks to Adam. Semi-cloudy pale yellow pour with a soft, bright white head. Huge tartness in the aroma. Tons of lemon, vanilla yogurt, sour lacto, wet hay, mineral water, sour stone fruit, light grain. Flavor is very clean. Minerals, sour grain & lacto, lemon, peach, under-ripe stone fruit, small amounts of yogurt & funky barnyard hay. Dry stone fruit & mineral finish. Absolutely incredible.

Bottle; minor gusher on opening. Pours hazy straw, very small white head with some lacing. Aroma is oaky, Brett, horseblanket, oak, lemon, wheat. Flavor is very light sweet, light tart, just a hint of funk; clean and crisp with a light oaky Brett touch. Light body, mineral water mouthfeel. Tasty

5/III/15 - 75cl bottle @ Drunken Drivers tasting (home) - BB: n/a, 2011 vintage (on cap) (2015-265) Thanks to Amy for giving me this bottle!
Clear pale yellowish beer, creamy irregular white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: bit funky, sourish, musty, spicy, some coriander, floral, bit sweet. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: very sourish, lemony start, little bitter, bit oxidized, sherry notes. Aftertaste: some cardboard, little funky, aged, bit thin, oxidized, sherry again. Too old or too barrel aged?

750 ml bottle to snifter (BATCH 06; shared with the Mrs.). Looks good; a hazy golden orange with foamy white head that dissipates into lacing. Smells and tastes good; funky brett and oak with a nice balance of pleasantly mild vinous notes alongside some yeast and a bit of citrus. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied and pleasantly lively. Good stuff.

Bottle 0.75l from tderoeck at Train direction Vichte to Alvinne Craft Beer Festival 2015. Thank you very much Tim for giving us homework :-).Pour it hazy orange color with small white head.On the nose spices, acid.Taste and aroma of liquer, vermouth, sour on some points.Ok interesting.

Bottle, shared by tderoeck on a train Ghent-Vichte direction ACBF (Belgium). Thank you Tim. Pours very hazy yellow with a minimal white head which leaves only lacing. Nose: sour distinctive accent, esters, spices, cellar. Mouth: mild cellar background in the palate, a bit watery but ok.

Bottle from tderoeck. Many thanks! Hazy yellow, almost no foam. Light carbonation. Fruity aroma, lemon, wheat. Bit bitter. Sour notes. Well balanced. Ok, but why do Americans call these beers saisons?

Thanks for sharing tderoeck! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ ACBF 2015. Batch #1. Murky golden. Nose is thick lactic with some vanilla, oak, malt sweetness; Taste is sweetish peach yeast, some sweetness, vanilla, mellow funk, very mellow tart. Low carbonation. Feels like it has been open a bit too long. Not optimal but quite nice all the same.

Can at Drunken Drivers Tasting @ tderoecks place. Thanks guys. Thanks to tderoeck for opening this bottle. Pours pale cloudy yellow. Nose is sour, white wine, little oxidated, lemon. Honey, sour, more white wine, watery taste.Nice.
Batch 5. Golden pour, white head. Tart vinous nose, a lot going on. Taste however is just huge oak barrel, way too oaky, some white grape, tart.

750ml bottle, batch 6. Poured on New Years Eve 2014, my last beer of the year, but also my first beer of 2015! 

Pours a vibrant golden-honey color. One finger fizzy white head that slows breaks into spotty lacing. Aromas of tart citrus, white grapes, wet oak, light hay, some barnyard. Taste is a bit tarter than I expected. Nice barrel notes gives this an acidic edge that I enjoy more than the fruited Floras. Nice wheat/grain gives this a medium body and a sweetness onto its own. Another dose of tart/funk hits towards the end as vinous notes harmonize with some oak sweetness that gives this a medium-dry finish. Delicious stuff!

Bottle at Hill Farmstead Beer Makers Dinner at Øl & Brød October 11th. Pours a pale yellow with a low white head. Aromas of citrus, honey, funk, gooseberry, oak, elderflower and slight nutty notes. Taste is citrus, funk, elderflower, gooseberry and funk along with some roaste notes from the barrel. Mouthfeel is crisp and dry with medium carbonation.

Pours clear pale yellow with low white head. Aroma of grass, light elderflower, apples, light grapes. Taste is rich tart, with a mellow lightly sweet finish. Body is light and crisp with soft carbonation.
Sampled at 2011 RBWG. Pours a cloudy yellow. Nose is bubblegum and esters. The taste is funk, citrus and sour wheat. Medium bodied. Nice Saison.
Bottle. Golden hazy pour with white head. Super fruity aromas, yeast and funk tones. Nice wine oak, yeast, fruit and juicy flavors.

2013 bottle thanks to Will. Pours a cloudy yellow orange with small frothy white head that lasts leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is strong white wine, oak, and biscuit dough. Thin mouthfeel with nice tart white grape, funk, light dry finish. Really enjoyed this.

(750ml bottle) cloudy bright gold, swirling makes little tiny carbonated bubbles appear, soapy white bubbles on top. Nose of wine barrel, lemon, micro flora, white pepper, complexity beyond description. Taste is slightly funky, spiced, red wine barrel, lemon, citrus pulp, deliciously complex and refreshing. Excellent palate linger.

A- pours a mostly clear straw yellow, with a flighty white head. Good lacing. S- decadent white grape, lemon zest, pineapple all tingle the nose. Brett notes, white pepper, wheat, pear, grass, soap and sweet cream butter on warm biscuits all collaborate on a full aroma. M- light to medium body with a bitter light to medium palate and sharp dry end. Good carbonation. T- minerals, lemon juice, tea are all forward. Pineapple and cobweb mixed in. Mid palate is salt, oak barrel funk, white grapes, brett, dust and light pepper. Ending is sharp and dry like the aroma and lingers towards a amicable but fulfilled end. Fresh cut grass, zinc, butter, grapefruit and sharp cheddar hold the end. A good way to wrap up the day.

750 ml bottled in July 2013, batch 5. Perfect crystal clear gold pour with correct level of carbonation. Aroma is indeed white wine with a wheat note underneath. 
Flavor is dry white grapes in the front of the sip with the Florence wheat base. For me personally Florence is my favorite HFS brew. This puts that base beer into another tier of flavor. Dry white grapes, light oak funk, wheat and a nice mellow tartness makes this a perfect summer brew. Simply fantastic, no need to ramble on. Like white wine? Like wheat based brews? This is a great marriage of the two.

750ml bottle shared thanks to Lukaduke! Pours cloudy pale straw yellow gold with a finger of head. Nose is musty tart lemon, citrus, damp oak, barrel, touches of rustic fruity yeast, a little funk. Taste is pillowy soft, tart lemon, citrus, pale grain wheat, dry woody oak, some dusty rustic yeast funk. Finish is dry and tart, earthy fruity yeast, golden apple, lemon. Spectacular!

Bottle shared at the CMLSG14 cellar tasting. Pours light yellow with a steady white head. Lively aromas of lemon zeste, white pepper and a hint of that typical spicyness in American saisons.. Light body with a nice dry finish. Lots of peach in the after-taste. Enjoyed this one very much.

Cloudy, yellow color. Aromas of lemon, brettanomyces and pineapple. Flavors of bretts, lemon and acidity. 
Couleur jaune. Nez de citron, bretts et ananas acide. Saveurs de bretts, citron et acidité.

Bottle shared at the 2014 tasting in the Cellar of Moeder Lambic Saint-Gilles. Pours cloudy golden with a small white head. Aroma of soft Bretty funk, citrus fruits, peppery saison yeast. Flavor is light sweet and light moderate sour with orange peel and vinous aspects in the palate. Medium bodied with light carbonation.
At big Seths going away party on 11/2/2013; was an awesome day! Aroma is brett, light gueuze tartness, soft oranges. Taset is light, balanced, vinigar, light acidity

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Re rated 11/29/14.  Pour is a completely transparent golden color with a tight white that lingers for a bit.  Nose is juicy, bright clean grape flavors, light oak, hints of pepper, faint dustiness.  Taste is similar, very strong bright grape flavors, a bit sweet, moderate oak and vanilla, a decent pepper note.  Well carbonated, light sourness, soft feel and consistent body.  


Pour a slightly hazed golden yellow with a fluffy white head. Nose has a light oak and hint of vanilla. Light mineral note, a bit if dusty cob webb brett with a bright lemon, hints of pepper and a lighter yeast note with a touch of soapy hop. Taste is actually a bit tart, a touch more soapy and the oaky vanilla flavors are more subtle. Still a bit of bright lemon juice and golden fruits that makes it rather enjoyable with a touch of mineral towards the finish. Body is light and drinkable with a moderate carbonation.

Just incredible!

Dark Golden pour with small off-white head. Citrus and funk with wheat notes. Dry, clean, citrusy. Medium body. Slighty sticky finish.
Excellent.

Bottled sample (batch 1) via and shared with oakbluff. Pale gold in colour with medium carbonation. Somewhat odd aromas of crabapple and white grape juice, cut grass, and iron. Flavors are of tart lime rind, hothouse flowers, and unbuttered popcorn. Extremely dry and light bodied. Tasted good as is, but I wonder if we hung onto this bottle just a little too long.

(Batch 2013): Arôme bretteuse, vineuse et florale, très effervescent et pointu. Les arômes se transposent en bouche de façon admirable, léquilibre est impressionnant. Finale sèche et vineuse et présence acétique, buvabilité naturelle.

12/4/2013. Hazy pale yellow with no head at all. This was almost like pouring soda. The head disappeared immediately. It may have been a bad bottle, but Im a bit disappointed. Bought this one at the brewery. Flavors were tart, sour with a bit of oak showing through, but I cant say I truly enjoyed this one.

From 375mm bottle. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Awesome. Tart, spicy, incredibly balanced. Lingering flavors of citrus. Incredibly crisp finish. Just an incredible beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy blond with a sticky soft foam head. The aroma is of light oak, wine, citrus, very floral, and yeast. In the flavor I got a weak vinegar taste, citrus, lemon, minor white grape, yeast, and wheat grains. The beverage is kind to the palate. The finish was pleasant and left a refreshing aftertaste. Overall a solid drink, very drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2013 Recent batch poured from a 750ml bottle, thanks Danny!  Beautiful, hazy straw-colored body yields copious white head & lace. White foam overstays its welcome, littering my glass after the liquid entered my belly. 

Soured grain meets funky microflora barrels.  Lemon-lime citrus peel among the Brettyness; funky all over. Just the right amount of tartness. Hay, grassy, earthy qualities are all present without stealing the spotlight (as they often do in this style). So smooth, so well-made. 

Dammit Shaun, this is awesome. Cheers.

Pours a hazy blond color with three fingers of fizzy white foam. The nose is light and spritzy with aromas of dew covered straw, floral grass and some zesty citrus and light notes of tropical fruit. The palate si fizzy and bright with lots of carbonation almost seltzer like with nice minerality and acidity... fuzzy lemon, hints of barnyard funk and floral wheat notes round out the palate and creates a soft complexity that is like no other beer Ive ever had. Beautiful beer.
Hazy yellow, white frothy head. Mild fruit flavor, lemon, citrus peel. Blows satsuma out of the water

Batch 3 and batch 4 bottles, about a week apart, poured into a Hill Farmstead glass. Flavor profiles and review notes were checked and were nearly identical for both batches.

Pour: A hazy, glowing light orange with a nice two finger white fluffy head. Head is pretty sticky and leaves very nice lacing. Body is quite radiant. 

Smell: Tart lemons and pear skin up front, followed by a light funk and light breadyness. Some white wine notes in there as well. A really nice oak comes through as it warms. 

Taste: Tart lemons, pear juice up front, and a white grape must. A light funk, and some bready sweetness. A little bit of oak towards the finish really rounds everything out. Finishes tart with lemon juice and is quite dry.

Mouthfeel: Insanely drinkable. The beer is supremely refreshing. Very juicy, yet equally dry. Begs you to have another sip right after the first.

Overall: This beer is perfect. More simplistic, yet more elegant than Juicy. More drinkable and flavorful than Civil Disobedience #5. Fantastic. If any difference between batch 3 and batch 4 were to be noted, batch 4 had a slightly greater wine barrel presence, potentially due to the longer maturation in the barrels

Pours a hazy golden with a nice white head that leaves great lacing. Aroma is composed of freshly cut hay, brett and citruses. Taste is tart (but not sour) and rustic. Fruity and winey, really nice! Light and refreshing, I could drink this all day. Awesome, really! I need more of this...

Bottle 750ml.
Pours slightly hazy blond with low white head (soapy-like). Good lacing. Aroma is of funk, citrus, fruits, yeast, bretts. Taste is of funk, citrus, acid, wine, yeast, bretts. Palate: Light body. Very refreshing. Overall: Awesome. Citric, rustic, fine.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by czar, thanks! Clear golden with a medium white head and good lacing. Aroma is of brettanomyces, wine, yeast, light to moderate tartness, fruity notes and floral notes. Taste is quite fruity with brettanomyces, wine, light tartness, floral notes and some lactic character. Medium body. Moderate to good carbonation. Winey mouthfeel. One of my favorite Saison from HF so far. The balance is nearly perfect, great complexity and high drinkability. The wine barrel treatment is very interesting and add to the complexity of the beer. Superb!

From Saturday'a tasting. Batch 5.
Light wheat aroma with soft fruit and phenolic notes. Fruit was citrus and phenolics were pepper and coriander. Yoghurt like acidity and light lactic notes. 
Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a small white head that showed good retention and moderate lacing. 
Flavor was fairly tart with some light yoghurt and lactic acid character. Medium citrus notes with some light wheat character. Light phenolics. 
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Low acidic astringency and low alcohol warmth. Tart but also some creaminess from the wheat.
Overall a fairly nice, tart saison. The tartness kind of hides the water qualities that I think make the saisons so special, but it also adds a nice complexity to the beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2014 Sampled at 2013 FOFA. Pours hazy golden with a lacy, white head. Aroma of oak, sourness/tartness, a little funk, and some pale and caramel malts. Flavor the same with a great blend of everything. Smooth texture. Another incredible Hill Farmstead beer.
Edit: Poured from a bottle.  Pours hazy, golden/amber.  Aroma incrdible with a great blend of everything I said before.
Edit: After FOFA 2014, this beer needs to be rated higher.  This was the best beer at the festival and the bottle share the night before.

Bottle shared at Collected Works tasting. Pungent grapefruit rind dominates the aroma. Flavor has a nice lemon Greek yogurt lactic character with pulpy key lime emerging in the back. Smooth, well-integrated tartness feels great on the palate.
750ml bottle @dmacs shared by Scott-dissipating white-hazy gold.  A-spice/mint, lt malt.  T-tart fruit, spice hops, lt malt, wood.
Excellent wild wheat beer. Sweet but only residually, rounded body. Drinks big for 5%. Long,  dryish finish. Top notch.

750 ml bottle shared at Cams tasting- thanks again! Pours a clear, pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of bretty and light fruity funk, white grapes, oak, lemon, and oak; the wine barrels are very apparent here. The flavor is tart, with barnyard, bretty funk, white wine, lemon, and oak. Light-bodied, with a tart, vinous, dry mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Nice beer. Easy to drink despite tartness and complexity. Enjoyable.
Draight from brouwerij lijn. Golden shiny pour white head. Zesty lemon with floral and fruits. Dry finish. Real good
Poured into my HF taster.  Bryan decided to share.  Pours a lovely light blonde color.  Subtle grass on the nose and hints of herbs.  Thin head quickly dispersed.  Smooth and easy drinking.
Poured into a mini snifter. Smells of chardonnay and a bit of tropical fruits. Taste is fantastic.... chardonnay and a nice zesty bite. Super dry finish. I want more.

Batch 2, capped but not corked 750 mL bottle share by Mr. Thorpe. Tasted with Art, Arthur, et al.

Color is cloudy, pale golden with a thick white head. Head fades quickly to a collar of bubbles with nice sheets of lacing. 

Aroma is a pleasant blend of funk, citrus, wheat, pale malt, straw, and grass. Some oak, but not as much as Art. 

Flavor starts similar to Art. Light saison yeast; more sweet than spice or funk, before some fruit and wine transition into a dry, wheat and yeast based finish. Lemon, grassy and herbal with subtle wine and oak tinges. Brett funk is present throughout, but not as strong as others have mentioned. Very unique and enjoyable. Similar body to other HF saisons, medium thick with a crisp, dry finish.

Havent tried both batches yet, but Number 2 is drinking well right now.

Bottle shared, unclear of the batch number. Pours with a clear yellow hued body with a small white head. Aromas are of tropical fruit, funk, floral, white wine, chamomile, lightly zesty and grainy. Bone dry, medium phenol. Flavors are of tropical fruit, chardonnay, toasted oak. Nicely funk phenols and esters, bone dry. Lively carbonation. My only complaint is a slightly overbearingly tannic finish.

Bottle with gold cap shared in Vail. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a hazy  golden color. Malty, lemon, citrusy, slight tart aroma. Lemon, white wine, spicy, yeasty, floral flavors. This is a mémórâblè liquid!

750 ml bottle.   Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a fluffy white head. The aroma is dry with a moderate funk, yeast, vinous white wine, citrus, pepper and earthy tones.  The flavor is dry grass, citrus, white wine, yeast, pepper, and very tasty.  Would like to have this again sometime.

Cracked open Sunday - traded for this after enjoying a similar bottle at my summer saison tasting. Batch 3 - poured into a tulip. Nice, golden color with a big white head. Loads of lacing too. Nose is earthy with a vinous lemony funk. Saison flavors punctuated with white wine and citrus. A dry finish. Crazy flavorful with a nice carbonation. Overall -a perfect summer session brew,

Bottle shared by Kyle, thanks! Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice funk note with light sweet fruit and light grains. Flavor has light funk and light sour fruit with some underlying earthy grain and grass.

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy golden orange with a medium white head and loads of orange sediment. Aroma of white wine barrels, barnyard funk and a bit of brett, though certainly dominantly characterized by the wine barrels. Flavour mirrors this, with a dominating white wine barrel presence, some tangy tartness, a little wheat and some yeast. Very vinous, with loads of depth. Highly drinkable and complex. Most excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013 Bottle shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike.

Served along side Hill Farmstead Art, Arthur, Civil Disobedience, and McKenzie Irma Extra.

The beer is yellow and hazy, with a sizable white head that leaves ample lacing on the snifter. The aroma brings brettanomyces, oak, citrus, pale malts, grain, yeast. The flavor is pretty good. Heavy on the brett character, and a bit unbalanced. Still, a tasty and enjoyable beer. Medium bodied with solid carbonation. Good beer. I would have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-02-2011

Deep honey pour with a fluffy ivory head.  Citrus, yeast, spice, oak, and vanilla in aroma.  Coriander, spruce, grapefruit, pepper, and some funky barnyard qualities are there.  Fruity and floral.  Buttermilk biscuit.  Good.

750ml bottle. Batch 1 (corked). Poured a yellow color with a large sized white head. Aromas of citrus, wheat, cereal, some lighter funkiness, and a trace of wood. Tastes of citrus, vanilla, the same lighter funk, and some lighter fruitiness.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 750ml. Batch 3. Pours cloudy yellow gold w/ thin white head. Very nice retention & lacing. Aroma is lemon zest, wheat, light funk, & a hint of sweeter fruit. Smells wonderful! Tastes of lemon, lactic, wheat, apple pie made w/ good tart apples, white wine, yeasty goodness, & faint wood. Delicious! Carbonation is very fine and finish is dry & wine like. I dig wild ales so this easily places amongst my favorite saisons.

Very light scent of doughy yeast and what I would describe as wet hay. Color is a hazy gold with a thin very light tan head. Taste is very sour with a light sweetness. Has a thin oily texture with soft carbonation. Im currently not a fan of sour beers, but this one is extremely well made and may change my mind.

Bottle shared by Sam. Golden hazy pour with lovely white head. Hoppy notes, wheat, and citrus all going on, with nice saison yeast and a hint of tartness. Unique mix of hefe-like notes, saison features, and the tart kiss of funk from the barrels.

Bottle a home with my wife, poured into my HF stemmed wine glass. Appearance is a glowing golden color with a small white head and great lacing. The aroma is funky, lemon peel, citrus, light spice, yeast, cheese and medicinal. Taste is tart lemon, wheat, honey, pepper, wax, barnyard, cheese, funky, and easy drinking. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Smooth, tart, herbal, spicy, and refreshing ending medium sour with a long-lasting tingly feeling that leaves my lips yearning for more. Really reminscent of a gueuze. A very delicious beer and well worth seeking out. Cheers!!

Big thanks to Sam for sharing another HF bottle with us! Beautiful pour, golden, forthy, and inviting. Prickly but not excessive carbonation. Nose is scrumptious, with plenty of dry hops, earthy wheat, and modest tartness in what promises to be a really distinctive saison. Taste follows through with this impression, and I love the way that the wheat brings out the more breadlike qualities of a saison without crossing over into biere de garde territory. Too, the subtle wine barrels create a twofold effect thats both tartly fruity and almost hefe-like in places somehow. Very good, very quirky.
Tap @ Festival of Farmhouse Ales.  I love beer that reminds me of lemonhead candy & this one hits it spot on.  Great wheat & lemon tartness, that signature light mouthfeel.  Wonderful!
tap at farmhouse fest. pours neon yellow with some white lacing. big sour aroma. taste is very thin bubbly and a little too funky for me

Draught at the Festival of Farmhouse Ales. Glowing pastel yellow with a fine head. Nose of lemon, yogurt, nice lactic character. Big lactic acid flavor, lemon, vanilla, alka seltzer. Soft, spritzy, clean, and lovely. Great wild character.

Bottle shared much thanks to Scott. Pours out a cloudy, golden color with a small white head. Aroma is of earthy notes, citrus, some lemon. Taste is of some nice tartness, lemon grass, lingering fruity notes, mild funk. Lots going on for the lower ABV

On tap at 2012 Hill Farmstead Festival of Farmhouse Ales. Big funky lambic-like nose, with a nip of manure and a tiny hint of baby diaper. Very raw and horsey. I like it. Sour. The grapefruit acidity was intense and delicious. Finishes with some great floral qualities. The most sour beer I had at the festival. I love the complexity of this. It reminds me of the awesome lambic-Saison hybrid Fantome La Gourmand. My festival favorite.

Every element of a perfect sour blonde is present in this sneaky, complicated saison.  Its bright and funky with all the tart-but-deep characteristics of wild yeasts; cherries, pineapple, vinegars, and dusty cheeses.  The white wine flavor of the barrel seems to be a perfect complement to the so lightly spicy, brisk flavor of the wheat.  Punchy but still somewhat soft palate, arresting in tartness but reticent and friendly in a slow finish; masterful.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 bottle. Pours gold with white foamy head, aroma floral pepper citrus honey flavors are sweet honey, pepper, florals, acidic finish, pretty good.3.7.

another pour at hill farmstead in 9/2012, pours blond with big white head. aroma has great tart and floral notes. flavors are tart, floral, lemony, crisp. very solid saison.

750 ml bottle shared by Scott at Deans poolside. Poured a hazy murky yellow body with a large dense foamy mostly white head. Aroma of dusty citrus, light wheat, some spice and pepper, funk and lemons. Medium to thinner bodied with softer carbonation and a slight sourness. Flavor runs very softly on the sour side of the spectrum, almost reminds me of a berlinerweiss, lemons and light wheat round this one out. Not getting a whole lot of the French oak that this was aged in.

Bottle shared at Muckfest III, no idea on the batch - Pours straw yellow, hazy with a foamy white head. Nose is light white pepper, dry spiciness, with light herbal and floral hopping. Taste is nice juicy tropical fruit, herbal hops, floral notes, with a soft, mineral finish. Smooth and bubbly carbonation--feels like velvet in the mouth. Excellent.
Effervescent and lively pour, like champagne. Batch 2. Aroma is earthy/mushroom, fecal and Doughy. Flavor is tart apples, floral(very rosy), slightly earthy. Finish is dry and oaky.

Pour at Scotts saison tasting, pour is hazy yellow with thin white head gusher out of bottle.  Aroma brought notes of sour lemon with lactic acid notes, touch of white wine, flowers, grass, some honey, tart fruits and slightly funky and musty.  Taste is nice sharp lemony lactic, hints of wine, tart fruits, touch of floral, honey and grass notes, touch of funk with a dry tart finish.  Very, very tasty.

At Tria Fermentation, poured a hazy golden straw yellow with a small creamy white head and active carbonation.  Aroma is wonderfully complex with notes similar to a fine oaky chardonnay including grass, golden delicious apples, pear, kiwi, and guava joined by slight dusty barnyard funk.  First sip is clean and crisp with flavors of citrus and tart fruits, tangy lemon, grassy hops, and wonderful wheat grains.  Exceptional mouthfeel with the carbonation dancing on the tongue and the flavors lingering on the palate.  Best saison Ive had to date.

750 ml bottle poured a clear yellow with a small lingering white head. Aromas of straw, barnyard, citrus and light yeast. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of straw, citrus, light horseblanket and light spice with a crisp dry tart lingering funky citrus finish.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Bottle @ Scotts Summer Saison tasting. Thanks so much Scott! The best of Scotts epic tasting. Muchas gracias! Gusher. Fairly clear, golden appearance with a bubbly white head. Spicy, well carbonated, mango/pineapple citrusy aroma that very nice. Quite tart and funky, pineapple, lemon, mango, tangy, somewhat spicy. So very tasty. (4.6)  Bottle with Jetson in Vail for Christmas. Batch 2. Pours a fairly hazy/cloudy, golden orange appearance with a white head, not as good of retention as Art. Vanilla, funky, dry vinous, big tropical fruity, tart mango aroma. Tart, juicy, pineapple, mango, dry wheat malty, vanilla, super refreshing flavor. R u jokin or wat, bro? Fuck yeah. (4.7)

From notes.  Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a tulip.  

Flora pours a dark golden color with a nice white cap.  

The aroma is lemony, a little bit like a gueuze.  Dry crackery malt and some funk add depth.  

The flavor is dry, with crackery malt up front, some wild sour flavors next, with a lingering lemon tartness.  There are some pear, green apple, and grassy notes in here as well.  The finish is fairly clean.

The body is dry, with medium carbonation and a lighter body.

Overall I felt this was a nice beer, pleasantly tart in a style that I do not normally enjoy as much.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours slightly hazy pale golden with a frothy white head that doesnt leave much trace or lacing while dissipating. Smell is sweet, spicy and funky with dusty barnyard, hay, green grapes, cloves, white pepper, tangerines, orange zest and hints of sweat. Taste is sweet and sour with dark grapes, lemon zest, dry soil, wood, barnyard, red wine, dandelions, brett and subtle hints of cheese. Mouthfeel is smooth, tiny dry and medium bodied. Finish is sweet, sour and tiny bitter with hay, cheese, grapes and barnyard. My first Hill Farmstead beer and considering the quality of this Im sure Ill track down many more.

(Bottle) Pours hazy pale golden with a white head. The aroma holds doughy yeast, tart white wine, tart fruits, sweaty horse/horse blanket, bread, crackers, citrus, herbs, flowers, dust, wood, cheese and subtle spices. The flavour is near dry and  light to medium acidic with a hint of bitterness. Notes of citrus, wine, tart grapes, mild funk, tart fruits, herbs, cheese, crackers and a touch of dough. The mouthfeel is soft, round and tart with a light carbonation. Tart, citric and a bit funky finish. Light to medium bodied.

Compliments of Jale at Flossmoors pre-DLD night.  Calling this a funky saison is pretty weak. Maybe I could italicize, bold, underline and further highlight the funky somehow to make my point. Really cool saison fellas. nice work.

Bottle, 75 cl. Hazy pale Beer with a dense, lively white head. Dry yeasty, floral, almost vinous aromas of apples, white wine, brett, wheat and flowers. The taste is citric, with a light floral malty sweetness, flowery hops, very crisp and fresh, light body. Elegant.

Batch 1 - What a difference a year makes!  I remember trying this a year ago and being unimpressed.  I imagine part of that is my palate changing, but am sure that the wild yeast has gone to work and improved this beer quite a bit.

Pours out a beautiful slightly hazy golden yellow with a pillowy, frothy white head.

Nose is impressive, lots of brett, some lemon zest, a bit of pepper, floral yeast, and a bit of earth.  Feel is excellent, light, crisp, dry, frothy.

Taste follows the nose - complex, earthy, a touch of lemon, and a bit of malt.

750ml bottle, marked with a hand-written "3".  Not sure what that means.  The pour yields a gorgeous, lightly hazy, golden-amber body strewn with ultra-fine streams of effervescing pinpoint bubbles.  A smooth, lightly spongy head of pure white foam recedes very slowly, never fully dissipating.  Ultimately, a paper thin center film leads to a slightly ramped-up edge, leaving tall, tattered splotches of lace all over the glass.  Pretty much a picture perfect brew.The nose is shockingly good.  It smells of the perfectly balanced and complex essence of expert barrel-aged saison craftsmanship.  Fresh-cut malted wheat is robust.  Softly buggy farmhouse yeast is dry and dusty.  Wisps of lightly peppery flower petals meet remnants of pungent grassy hops.  And then theres the barrel influence.  Oh that barrel makes everything even better.  Soft Pinot Noir tannins lend a fruity, aromatic bite, and lambic-esque lacto-citric acidity keeps things wild and dry.  Tart, buggy, woody, sharp...it simply smells amazing.The flavor is also exceptional.  Wheat plays such a prominent role...probably more so than in any other saison Ive ever had.  The cereal-esque base is so distinct, and it works beautifully with the slightly dank grassiness of the hops.  Nips of tart, tangy lemon and dried pineapple meet dusty wildflowers, wild farmhouse yeast, and funky, woody barrel bugs.  Acidity slices right through the ever-so-slightly creamy malts.  Damn tasty stuff.  Not as mind-blowing as the aroma, but great nonetheless.The palate?  Its dry, dusty, and zippy, with a moderate body and a crisp finish.  The only downside is a a hint of papery character that is easily overlooked.  I drank the bottle over the course of a few hours with tremendous joy.  This is an excellent freaking beer.  Look...the case is pretty much closed.  Shaun Hill brews the best saisons in America...maybe the planet.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Glowing golden yellow body, large creamy white head. Assertive lemon zest, wheat, tropical citrus,grassy hops, and yeasty zip. Light bodied, good carbonation keeps the flavors moving across the tongue.  A clean, vibrant saison that is perfect for a warm spring afternoon.

Pours mostly translucent with a nice off white head. The aroma, my favorite part, is so sweet and pleasant with notes of sweet earthy honey and delightful saison yeast tame on funk and spice but so nice. The flavor brings sweet, grassy notes like a refreshing walk in a spring meadow on a perfect just right carbonated body.
On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a hazy orange-blonde. This stuff is damn delicious. So clean with delicate notes of lemon and wheat. I dont know how they do it; its subtle but so addicting.

Cant remember if it was a bottle or on tap at Matts. Hazy bright yellow pour. Aromas of leather, oak, tropical citrus, and pine. Flavor is filled with white wine, pineapple, slightly bitter and orangey hops. Very very good.

Hill Farmstead saisons are the best period!  Like always it poured a beautiful hazy yellow with billowy foamy white head.  Aroma is moderate funk, lemon, apple, and dough.  Taste was lightly funky and tart with citrus fruits and nice cracker malts.  Topped only by Mimosa in my saison wall of fame.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2013 I shared this one with everyone after the bottle share a few weeks back. Bought it at the Brass Rail for way too much money...I believe it was a Batch 2


A - Pours murky golden yellow with a nice one finger tall white head leaving very light streaks of lace down parts of the glass.


S - Smells of typical saison funk, lemon, green apples, fresh cut grass, oak and some wet earth. Nothing too complex yet still very nice.


T - Starts off with some fruitiness - mostly citric fruit and fresh green apples - quickly giving way to hints of oak, grass, damp earth and plenty of chewy wheat. I was expecting a bit more funk, all tho I am not sure if it needs it. Finish is dry, lingering on the pallet long after consumption.


M - Light body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Fairly dry finish lingers on the pallet for quite awhile after each sip.


O - I had the base beer of this one and thought it was decent but this one is definitely an improvement on that one. The barrels really helped to round things out. Good stuff for sure.

Bottle, pours a really nice foamy head. Bright yellow pour. The aroma is very floral and funky. Its got a nice funk to it the whole way through. This stuff tastes almost like a light lambic. Its got that lambic feel a good light body. Very solid for the style

Batch 3, pours clear medium gold with a medium white head.  Lemon, cracked black pepper on the nose, fresh grains.  Quite herbal and peppery, not as hop forward as I would have thought.  Really sharp and sour in the mouth.  Mineral/sulfur on the front palate with sour orange and lemon.  Back palate is all brett, really sweaty, socky brett,  Truly funky, in fact this defines funk.  Flavor profile is totally fleshed out and is really vibrant at this young age, but its weird and a bit fucked.  Tastes like sweaty underwear all through the finish for a good 30 seconds.  Carbonation is sharp.  Flavors approaching vaginal.  Still pretty good, wink! ;-)

Flora pours a cloudy pale yellow.  Nice fluffy white two finger head is poured.  Decent retention and lacing throughout the glass.  A ton bubbles shoot from the bottom of the glass.  Nicely carbonated.

The smell on this one is nice and delicate.  Wheat of course, floral hops, lemon, orange, white grapes.  Im used to barrels doing more but its done very little to this beer.

The barrel does a little but more in the taste.  The grape characteristics stick around more this time especially at the end and after taste.  Its a crisp delicate taste.  Once again lemon, wheat, citrus, and some nice tartness.  Not a overwhelming tartness, just a tad.  Lovely taste.

Mouthfeel is medium bodies, crisp, and well carbonated.  Carbonation smacks the lips.  Dry finish.

Really did enjoy this one.  Its refreshing.  The barrel doesnt do much here other than adding some grape characteristics and the wild yeast adds a slight tartness to it.  Nothing overwhelming here.  Just a nice balance of everything.
On draft pour 2010 vintage/.  Nice yellow color. Light and clean with the right amount of funk.  Did well in the barrels.

Bottle shared by Brad at Jackie Os. Clear gold pour with a huge white head. Malty nose with notes of funk, tartness and wine. Sweet malt flavor at first, then tart fruit and wine take over before a funky finish. Very nice.

Batch 3 - Poured into some Hill Farmstead stemware.  Beautiful, clear, golden body with two fingers worth of frothy white head.  Lots of patchy white lacing traces the glass.  Earthy wheat grains on the nose with some slight barnyard funk.  Touch of lemon citrus.  The flavor is filled with juicy citrus and wheat.  A light, dry, sourness lingers throughout.  Barreled wine character in the background.  Much more flavorful than previous batches of Flora.  Mouthfeel is smooth, almost slick, with spritzy carbonation.  Overall, this is a really nice improvement on the original batches of Flora.  An excellent Belgian-styled table beer.

Purchased at the Hill Farmstead Beer Release on February 18th. Kept in the fridge and poured into an HFS glass.

A - 1-Finger crystal clear head with cream like bubbles. The beer itself is golden to leather in appearance. Its a very hazy beer with some nice sediment floating around.

S - Wheat is the dominant scent followed by Kiwi, Mango and lots of grapes. Im getting really sweet green grapes.

T - In short, a carbonated Pinot Noir with wheat and bitter yeast. I love wine so this has those Pinot tastes in a very balanced way. The wheat in this beer is very apparent.

M - None of HFSs beers really take over your mouth with carbonation when you swish. This is no different. Solid mouth feel, light bodied and a pleasant white grape juice aftertaste. 

O - Utterly remarkable. This beer is simply a fantastic wheat saison with the drinkability of white wine. We had this beer with baked fish and it paired very well! Delicious, drinkable, perfect.

On tap at the brewery - a pre EBF sample that Sean generously provided before it was kegged. Pale light yellow, white head. Lemon, light orange, tart and sour, some vinous notes. Tart and bretty, moderate carbonation, lemon, full body, some interesting spice and a bit of dryness on the end as well. Quite tasty.

[bottle] shared by Andrew. Thanks! Pours clear gold with a fine whitish head. Aroma is mineral, lemon, lightly herbal. Not super complex, but bright and balanced. Flavor is light, citrus, mineral, super drinkable, nice.

Bottle @ Jews brews and bbqs. Canary yellow, slight haze. Aroma is predominantly lactic with lemon zest and candied lemon rind. Light on the palate with very light soft effervescence. Finishes clean, with a saltiness that adds a nice element. Its refreshing. Underwhelming overall but nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to MtGoat.  Pours bubbly straw gold, hazy, with a thin creamy head that just sits there looking pretty.  Nose has brett, pineapple and white wine grapes, floral hops and soft lemon wheat. Taste begins with light tartness and vinous quality,  leading into some brett character, bread malts, soft lemon overtones, and dry light herbal bitter finish. Dry, smooth and creamy in the mouth, very easy to enjoy.  Delicious, will definitely look for more.
Bottle.  Pale yellow pour with a small white head.  Tart citrusy nose.  Light, smooth, and crisp with citrus, cereal, and light Pinot Grigio notes.  Well done..

tap at hill farmstead.   beautiful rustic flower, lemongrass, and wheat with am earthy, cheesy, old cellar brett funk.   some white wine grapes.   dry.   rustic, earthy saison.   fresh cut wild flowers on a fall day.   awesome beer.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2011 This is one of my favorite beers of all time. Pours a clear golden hue with a billowing white head. Lots of sticky lacing. Smell is super saison esters, some funky brett with a floral wine oak smell. wheaty malt come through. The esters coming off this liquid are potent and clean. taste is a blast of flavors from malt, clean yeast esters, brett leather, wine barrel, oak, light vanilla finishing with a light bite of hop crispness. touch of hop taste but mostly lending a nice crisp bite. mouthfeel is medium body with high crisp drying carbonation. overall this is one of the finest beers ive ever had.

Poured from a corked 750 ml. bottle thanks to Eric for sending this. Light golden color with a bit of haziness. Thin but nice white head. Aroma off the top is lemon, wheat, yeast, and funk. Light in body and some prickly carbonation. Interesting mix of flavors with a flowery herbaceous quality along with hints of the Pinot barrel. A definite funky quality with maybe a slight acetic bite. The hop presence is there as well. A good beer and unique  but maybe not my favorite HFS Saison.

750ml, batch 2(?). This was one of the best beers had on tap during Philly Beer Week 2011 so Im excited to try it in bottle form.

Pours a hazy pale golden orange color with golden yellow hues when held to a light and a large two finger frothy, pillowy white head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves chunks of soapy lacing behind.

Slightly earthy aroma with subtle farmhouse funk from the saison yeast with hints of barn/wet hay. Additional funk from the wild yeast with hints of earth, grass and straw which are complimented by the oak barrel presence. Im not picking up much of a wine presence but the wheat elements of the beer stand out under all of the other things going on. Hints of zesty spice, notably pepper and love as well as some bready yeast, banana, apple, pear and lemon peel. Very complex nose on this beer.

Medium bodied but on the fuller end of the spectrum with a flavor profile thats almost as complex as the nose suggests. Dry, earthy and funky up front from the saison yeast giving off hints of hay, grass and straw which compliments the dry, funky wild yeast notes. These bugs create a funky effervescence thats more dry than tart. Think more like Orval than like Temptation. The wine barrel aging further compliments this component with dry toasted oak notes and a very slight vinous light fruit character. Again, Im not picking up much wine but there is a sweet fruit presence, mostly apple and pear and some noticeable wheat beer characteristics. Zesty spice notes, especially pepper and clove balanced by sweet citrus peel and a prominent bready yeast character that adds fullness to the body. Lingering dry finish.

Overall this beer is incredibly complex, well balanced and delicious. Its such a strange amalgam of flavors but it works really well here. These factors along with the low ABV make it incredibly quaffable. I have to stop myself from pounding down the whole 750 too quickly. I was a little skeptical of Hill Farmstead at first but Im quickly coming around after drinking this Galaxy and Double Citra. Highly recommended!

A generous white foam decorates the gently hazy pale gold. A pretty fruity and funky nose with pleasant bretty tones, but less pleasant barrel gone wild notes of acetone and bee wax. The barrel provides a greasy, buttery vanilla side that I dont dig much, but fortunately, its only a facet among many others. The Pinot remains subtle, you could call the nose grapey, but with the butteryness, Id have thought more along the lines of a California Chardonnay. The fruitiness takes more of a citrusy twist, providing soft lemony flavours that gently complement the gentle floral  hop nuances. Earthy and leathery palate with a fairly funky presence that remains in check. Unagressive carbonation, especially after the beer has settled down for a few minutes, its thin-medium body and focused dryness ensure good drinkability. Some very interesting elements but Im hesitant. For a 5.5% Saison, it is fairly complex, particularly for a beer that deploys just a touch of tartness rather than outright acidic complexity and dry palate... yet there are some aromatic components in there that I would just prefer to do without. Id gladly try again as these wild beasts can legitimately vary, but Id empty the shelves of Hill Farmsteads Art before!

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2012 My Bottom Line:
This Barrel-Aged Saisons subtle coniferous wilderness dallies alongside delicate flower petals and wine barrel fruitiness, as invigorating citrus and wheat fade into a dry, tart finish. 

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sizeable head of foam decorates the top of the shiny pale gold.
-The unusually prickly effervescence (for a HillF brew) enlivens the soft, dry mouthfeel.
-This smells like a cousin of Jolly Pumpkin but, for now, it is not as tart or expressive in its wilderness. This is much more drinkable and approachable for those who would like to discover wild yeasts.
-The restrained bitterness and quiet hoppiness in the finish make for a clean, uneventful finish.
-Wheat almost takes over in the second half of each sip.
-This has evolved wondrously over the last year. I dont know how long Id keep aging it, but a year has given it even more room to express itself.

Bottles.
